turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Yah -- she's damn near as good as that little black fella -- with the glass eye.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Sammy Davis, Jr., honey.

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, the Jew.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Hey! Turn that float around. You think a swan's gonna swim ass first up Main Street?

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Yah -- Gladys had me order that swan special made from Mexico  in case Becky won. I do a lotta business with those people. I always offer to pay 'em in tacos.  Whoo, they love that.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Hey, Ted, sorry. I didn't know your family was in the garage when I set it on fire!

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: Gladys! Stop it!

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Guess it wasn't a garage sale as much as it was a bake sale. Ah- hahahahahahahaha!

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: So help me, Gladys.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Becky was my only shot at state!

turns.speaker: LESTER
turns.text: That's enough!

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Let go! Let go of me. Oh my God, it's COPS!

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: ...that filth is better left in the "Sin Cities."

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: A.k.a. Minneapolis -- St. Paul.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: ...Today's "To Do" list includes a trip to the Mall of America. We need outfits for the "Physical Fitness" number --

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Nothin' too showy!

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Y'betcha, Iris. We still need a third judge and we need to think of a theme.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Gladys -- Gladys! Look out!

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Oh, my!  Hello, Father Donigan! Sidewalks, sidewalks?

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Iris, stop!  It's not his fault. The communal wine just proves too temptin' for some of them.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: That's why we Lutherans use grape Koolaid for the blood of Christ.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Oh, there's a parking space over there. Oh, no, that's just a compact. Sorry.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: You'd think they'd build the parking lot of America to go with the Mall of America!

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: It's a two-hundred dollar fine!

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: I said I'd move if a cripple came. Let's just run in the store and pick out some outfits.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: All right, let's go.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Oh! What is it?

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: "Proud... to be... an... American."

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Well, you know, I think everyone's doing really well considering the fact that she was so young.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: It's always hard to see the young ones called home, especially on an exploding thresher. It's just so odd and gross.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: You know that sometimes it's hard to understand God's great plan.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: So, remember the three most important parts of a good interview...

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Okay, everybody, listen up!

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Number one, American Teen Princess' don't cross their legs like streetwalkers.

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: Okay, I designed the float, you know. And, what's gonna happen here is that this is going to look like a glistening lake beneath the swan.

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Uh, Gladys?

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: We need more bars!

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: This is -- what?

turns.speaker: IRIS
turns.text: Enid ate a whole pan!

turns.speaker: GLADYS
turns.text: I swear to God she can't do anything by herself.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Are we on "Cops?" Are we on "Cops?" Are we on "Cops?"

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Shut up, Hank. This here's business.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Ow, Harold -- Mom said not the head.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Well, Mom's dead, so shut your fly trap.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: I will if you shut your piehole.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Don't make me kick-ya where the good Lord split-ya.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Close up shop. Close up shop, Hank.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: Harold!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Close up shop!

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: EE-AAAYEEEE-AAAAYOUIAAAEEEEEEEE!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Come on! Hankey here can't help it if he was born crazier than a shithouse rat!

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: Let's get this straight right now. We wouldn't have been late at all if it wasn't for you.

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: I want to have the big bag of little donuts.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: You get nothing, Hank, okay?

turns.speaker: HANK
turns.text: I want to get the big bag of little donuts.

turns.speaker: HAROLD
turns.text: There's your paint can. The next time you drink window cleaner, I'm just gonna leave it in ya.

turns.speaker: TINA
turns.text: Excuse me, Father, Mother, when are we moving back to Tokyo? I can't stand this place anymore. They put butter on everything.

turns.speaker: MR. HOWARD
turns.text: English! English, you stupid little retard! We America now, Tina!

turns.speaker: TINA
turns.text: I'm sorry, Dad, but with all due respect, my name isn't "Tina," it's Seiko.

turns.speaker: MR. HOWARD
turns.text: Tina! Tina!! TINA!!!

turns.speaker: TINA
turns.text: Mom, I just finished the third movement of that concerto I was working on. I put, like, this techno beat on this Japanese folk tune -- wanna hear it?

turns.speaker: MR. HOWARD
turns.text: No! We not like to hear it! Go to your room and shut up!

turns.speaker: TINA
turns.text: Oh, I almost forgot...  I got my acceptance to Tokyo University.

turns.speaker: MR. HOWARD
turns.text: What, you deaf? I say shut up -- shut up -- SHUT UP!  Cut her outta this!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: From what I have been gathering, I think they think I should be king: I think they think I should be king!

turns.speaker: ALL
turns.text: He should be king!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: And wear a crown and everything.

turns.speaker: ALL
turns.text: And everything.  He should be king!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Of course you're All aware a king must have an heir some one to pass the family name along will some one tell me where I'd ever get an heir if a king can do no wrong

turns.speaker: ALL
turns.text: The king can do no wrong!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Suppose a pretty dame Into my castle came - And let us say that I was going strong.  She might be stuck on me, but what good would it be, if the king can do no wrong.

turns.speaker: ALL
turns.text: The king can do to wrong!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: King Solomon was game he gave each Girl his name to number them would make a list that long I'll bet his thousand wives led miserable lives if the king can do no wrong.

turns.speaker: ALL
turns.text: We really think he should be king and wear a crown and everything.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: They think I should - They think I should - They think I should - They think I should be king.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Here I am, Father.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Take a letter.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Who to?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: The President of the United States.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: My dear President...  read it back...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: "My dear President"...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That doesn't sound right...  take out "President"...  now read it.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: "My dear"...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's not right yet... put back "President" and take out "dear"... How does it read now?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: "My President"...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: There's still something wrong with it... take out "President" ...now what've you got?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Now we're on the right track... Put back "dear"... How does it read?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: "My dear"...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You can't say that to the President... Put back "President"... Now let's hear how sounds.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: "My dear President"...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's what I wanted in the first place.  Tear it up and send it airmail.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Is that all?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Take another letter...  to my tailor.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Dear Sir... enclosed find check for $100.  Yours very truly...  Send that immediately.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I'll have to enclose the check first.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You do and I'll fire you.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Here I am, Father...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Send for my car...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: His Excellency's car!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Go out and chase that peanut vendor away from the building -- Get rid of him if you have to use violence - if necessary call out the militia and if he isn't looking get me a bag of peanuts.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I've tried to chase him but it's no use - he won't go -

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: He won't eh? - We'll see about that - send for your father immediately.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: But you're my father -

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Never mind then, I'll get in touch with him myself -

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: In case of fire, how long will it take to empty this place?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: About - thirty-four seconds.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: We'll start a fire --  -- and get rid of these microbes.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Father...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Take a letter...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Who to?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: None of your business...  Take another letter.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Eureka Ammunition Company -- Gentlemen -- Your shipment of sailor hats arrived this morning by freight --  Gloria, I could go for you in a big way --  However, the rifles you sent were a little rusty --  -- and I don't say that to everybody --  Have not received last month's drawing account.  How come?  Your neck is like a swan...  Yours very truly.  Now read it back.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Eureka Ammunition Company, Gentlemen. Your shipment of sailor hats arrived this morning by freight.  Gloria, I could go for you in a big way. However, the rifles you sent were a little rusty and I don't say that to everybody.  Have not received last month's drawing account; how come your neck is like a swan.  Yours very truly...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: They'll know I mean business then they get that letter...  see that that gets out immediately and that goes for you too.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Gloria, much as I hate to leave, I'd be crazy to stay here.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: I wonder what's keeping His Excellency?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Never mind His Excellency -- you gotta your pocketbook?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Yes -- why?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I wanna powder my nose...

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: In her dressing room?  Why, what could he be doing there?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: He could be playing solitaire, but I don't think so.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: What's the matter with you?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: You haven't been still a moment since you've been here.  You act as if you had neurosis --

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I no gotta new-rosis.  My uncle he's- a got a flower shop -- he's-a gotta new-rosis.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Hey you!!

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: All right -

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Have you got a license?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: No, but my dog he's a got millions of them --

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: What kind of a dog is he?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: He used to be a bloodhound but he's anemic --

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well - what is he now?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: He's half poodle and half watch dog -

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Half watch dog?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Yeh, he's only got one eye.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I don't know much about dogs but you ought to be on the end of a leash - a ninety-nine year leash -  Look - what do you call your dog?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I don't call him, I whistle.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: What do you whistle?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Yankee Poodle.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I've got just the place for a man like you but I'm too busy right now to do any digging.  What do you call your dog when you want him?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I don't want him.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, if you don't want your dog why don't you put him in a pound?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: He only weighs ten ounces --

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I can use you in the House of Representatives.  We need a man who understands dogs -- and that's where this country is going to.  Step inside.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: That was for you.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I'm sorry I'm not in.  I wanted to have a long talk with you...  Now look here, my good man, you've got to stop yelling "peanuts" in front of the House of Representatives.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Oh no, I can't do it.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You don't want to be a public nuisance, do you?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Sure.  How much does the job pay?  Sure, if there's a chance for advancement.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You wouldn't consider going over Niagara Falls without a barrel?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: 'At's-a no good.  I went to Niagara Falls once.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Did you shoot the rapids?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: No, but I shot some ducks.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: If there was an open season for fellows like you, I'd get myself a hunting license.   Anyway, I'm going to make you a sporting proposition. You give up the peanut stand and I'll make you vice-president of the country.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Oh, no -- nothing doing.  I had a brother who was a vice-president once and that's the last we ever heard of him.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, maybe he's still the vice- president.  Now if I were to offer you --

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Hello...  Yes...  No, not yet... All right...  Goodbye.  That was for you again.  He wants you to call him up as soon as you get back.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I don't know what's keeping me.  I should've been here a long time ago. Now how about my proposition?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: What other job you got?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Let's see -- What've I got in my cabinet besides mice --  I've got it -- how would you like to be Secretary of the Interior?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: That's no good.  I like to work on the outside.  I must have something easy.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Then you don't wanna work hard?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I don't wanna work at all.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: In that case you'll have to take a civil service examination --  if you pass I'll put you in the post-office -- stick out your tongue.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I don't wanna stick out my tongue.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, if you wanna work in the post- office you'll have to stick out your tongue.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Look, I'm a very nervous man.  I gotta have a job where I come to work at eleven -- go to lunch at twelve -- and quit at one.  And twice a year I gotta have a six month vacation.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I've got just the job for you -- Secretary of War.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: 'At's-a fine.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You know, I'd be lost without a telephone.  Now - where were we? Oh, yes - I just made you Secretary of War.  The first thing you do is buy ammunition -- you buy it from me and I get 10% commission.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: What do I get?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You get half mine and I get half yours.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I don't want to buy ammunition -- we no gotta war.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Then we've gotta start one. Do you know how to start a war?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Sure, that's easy.  You gotta insult somebody.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: My card.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: That's a-no good.  You gotta insult somebody from another country.  Look --  I come from one country.  You come from another country.  I say something you don't like.  You say something I don't like - and I'm insulted.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Why wasn't I insulted?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: You was insulted, but you don't know it.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Then I demand an apology!

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: That's a-no good.  If I apologize we no got a war.  Look -- I send you a scrap of paper.  You send me a scrap of paper -- and we have a scrap.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You've got a brain after all - and how you get along without it is amazing to me -- Now, who can I insult?...  Who do we owe money to?...  AMBASSADOR TRENTINO!  How about him?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: He's-a very easy to insult --  I say something to his niece once, and he slapped my face.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Why didn't his niece slap your face?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: She did.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: What did you say to her?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You're lucky I don't slap your face -- you oughtta be ashamed of yourself. Where did you hear that story?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: You told it to me.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Oh, yes, I remember -- and I should have slapped Mrs. Teasdale's face when she told it to me... I'm going right out and find Trentino.  You go right out and get yourself an army.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Wait a minute.  What kind of an army do you think we oughtta have?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I think we oughtta have a standing army, so we can save money on chairs.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Send in the next girl.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: By the way, are you sure we need a spy?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Sure, we gotta have a spy.  If we no got a spy who's gonna tell the other side what we're doing?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I'm glad I didn't ask you for "Washington Crossing the Delaware".

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: We've gotta have somebody who knows how to get secrets from men.  You know how to make love?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: He's going to make a good spy... that's not bad for the first day.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's not bad for any day.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You're right about that guy -- I think we've got something.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I don't know about us, but I know he's-a got something...

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: You no gotta no gun.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Who said I had a gun... Gimme those plans, you paper snatchers --

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Late again, eh?  You haven't been on time once since this war started...  Get out there and fight...

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I can't do it...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Why not?  You're the Secretary of War, aren't you?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Yes, but I'm not working for you any more.  I'm on the other side.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Is that so?  I used to think you were two-faced - but you can't be - or you wouldn't be wearing that one. Now - let's talk this thing over.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Now -- how many men you got in your army?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Well, we gotta one hundred thousand men.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's not fair -- we've only got fifty thousand.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: That's all right.  We let you have twenty-five thousand men -- and we both start even.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's the spirit -- fifty-fifty.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: No. Seventy-five -- seventy-five.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, we'll let that one go.  Now -- how many battalions you got?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: We gotta two battalions and one Frenchman.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I wish you were still working for me, so I could ask you to resign. How're ya fixed for cavalry?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I've gotta five thousand men but no horses.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's funny, we've got five thousand horses but no men.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: That's all right -- our men can ride your horses.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Not a bad idea.  If our horses get tired they can ride your men for a change.  Now, I don't mind letting you have our horses, but you must promise to put them through their maneuvers.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Oh, sure.  We have horse maneuvers every morning.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: With a gun like that you can kill some of your own men.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: That's-a pretty good.  I'll take a dozen of them.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Anything else?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Yes, one gross of bullets, two dozen hand-grenades, three kegs of powder -- and throw in some matches.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Fine.  We'll throw in the matches before we make the delivery.  By the way, how're you fixed for spys?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Fine.  We gotta him.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: So! -- He's on your side, too.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, with you two fellows on the other side, this country should have no trouble keeping the wolf from the door.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: How'm I doing, boss?

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Fine - keep on yelling - Do everything you can to disturb Firefly - Now what about your cousin?

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: He's working very hard - I got him a job driving Firefly's car - He's-a driving him crazy and I'm driving him nuts - P-E-A-N-U-T-S

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Chicolini, you've come just in time. We need a man who's fearless, brave. A man who's willing to die, if necessary.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: All right -- I'll go out and find one.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Firefly must be captured at any cost.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: That's easy, I'll get him for you wholesale.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: It must be done right away.

turns.speaker: CHICO
turns.text: I can't do it right away.

turns.speaker: ENSEMBLE
turns.text: We're not allowed to tell a dirty joke HAIL, HAIL, FREEDONIA

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: If chewing gum is chewed, The chewer is pursued And in the hoosegow hidden...

turns.speaker: ENSEMBLE
turns.text: If we should choose to chew, we'll be pursued -

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: If any form of pleasure is exhibited Report to me and it will be prohibited.  I'll put my foot down; So shall it be - This is the land of the free.  The last man nearly ruined this place He didn't know what to do with it.  If you think this country's bad off now Just wait 'till I get through with it.  The treasury is low on dough; The last man went and flew with it.  If you think we're short of money now Just wait 'till I get through with it.  The country's taxes must be fixed - And I know what to do with it, If you think you're paying too much now, Just wait 'till I get through with it.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I will not stand for anything that's crooked or unfair; I'm strictly on the up and up, So everyone beware. If anyone's caught taking graft And I don't get my share, we'll stand 'em up against the wall - and pop goes the weasel!

turns.speaker: ENSEMBLE
turns.text: So everyone beware Who's crooked or unfair; No one must take a bit of graft Unless he gets his share.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: If any man should come between A husband and his bride, We find out which one she prefers By letting her decide.  If she prefers the other man, The husband steps outside; We stand him up against the wall And Pop goes the Weasel!

turns.speaker: ENSEMBLE
turns.text: The husband steps outside; Relinquishes his bride; We stand him up against the wall And take him for a ride.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: The population must increase With great rapidity.  We give a couple seven years To raise a family. If, by that time, there is no branch Upon the family tree, we stand 'em up against the wall - and Pop goes the Weasel.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Your Excellency, please don't think me silly, but I'd love to have a picture of you.  I want to hang it in my bedroom.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You couldn't hang me in your bedroom -- I'll make a note of it.  Where's my secretary?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You keep that up and you'll crab the whole war.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Carry out this tragic folly if you will -- But I for one will not be a part of it.  I will stay here in Freedonia.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Oh, Your Excellency, isn't there something I can do?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Yes, but I'll talk to you about that when we're alone...

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: I shall dance for you tonight as I've never danced before.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: This is a fine thing to be doing at my age.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Are you getting tired?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Not at all.  When I was a boy back on the farm I used to pump my own water.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Are you sure you're not tired?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Tired!  I'd like to stretch this into a week -

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's even a greater honor.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: I bring you the greetings of my President and the good will of my people.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I'll keep the greetings -- but you can send back the good will... what we need right now is twenty million dollars.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Twenty million dollars is a considerable sum...  I'll have to discuss that with my Minister of Finance.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, in the meantime, could you let me have $50 personally?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I'll tell you what I'll do.  I'll give you Mrs. Teasdale as security.  or my jackknife.  If you want my advice, you'll take the jackknife... I've a better proposition...  Make it $25 and I'll give you a first mortgage on my son and I hope you foreclose.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Your Excellency, haven't we met before?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Why yes.  I met you at the dog races -- say, you could have won that race if you tried a little harder.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Excellency, may I present my niece.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: You don't understand.  This is my niece Vera.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: And Vera niece, too.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: When you get through with her feet, you can start on mine.  I haven't been to a chiropodist in two years...  If that's not an insult, I don't know what is.  Gloria, I love you.  I --

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Can't we go some place where we can be alone?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: What can this mug offer you?  Wealth and family.  I can't give you wealth...  ...but we can have a little family of our own.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: This has gone far enough!  This interruption is humiliating, to say the least...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, why not say the least and get it over with?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's what you think.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: You swine!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Give me that again!

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: You worm!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Once more!

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: You upstart!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's it!  No man lives who can call a Firefly an upstart.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Then it's war?

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: How're ya fixed for ammunition?

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Bah!!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: THEN IT'S WAR!

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: I'm sorry we lost our tempers... I'm willing to forget if you are.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Forget?  You ask me to forget... Why, my ancestors would rise from their graves... and I'd only have to bury them again... A Firefly never forgets...

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: I am willing to apologize...  I'm willing to do anything to prevent this war.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Nothing doing!!  I've taken a lease on the battlefield.  I'd lose my deposit, besides, I've already ordered the ammunition...

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: What I called you...  Why, what did I call you?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I don't remember.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Oh -- you mean... worm?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: No, that wasn't it...

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Was it -- swine?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: No... it was a seven letter word.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Oh yes! -- UPSTART!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's it...

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Why - er - Mrs. Teasdale - this is an outrage!  This man is impossible... My course is clear...  this means war...  You RUNT!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I still like UPSTART the best.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: What'll I do with this card?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You can keep it -- I've got a whole pack...  Now what were you saying?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: In choosing you, I feel that I serve my country well.  I heartily endorse everything you stand for.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, I won't stand for much.  And I won't stand for you if you don't show some improvement soon.  Look at your report card last month -- "D" in spelling...  six in behavior. Now who were the six?  A fine state of affairs -- no wonder you can't matriculate, now what were you saying?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: The future of Freedonia rests upon you.  Promise me you will follow in my husband's footsteps.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I haven't been on the job five minutes and already she's making advances to me.  Not that I care -- but where is your husband?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Why - er -- my husband passed away...  I was with him to the very end.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: No wonder he passed away.  I'd like to be with you to the very end. Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you -- I love you.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Your Excellency!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You're not so bad yourself, Mrs. Teasdale, when I look at you I can see that we're facing a crisis. We've got to balance the budget -- we've got to cut down everything including, you.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Your Excellency, the eyes of the world are upon you.  Notables from every land are gathered here in your honor --  This is a gala day for us.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, a gal a day is enough for me. I couldn't handle any more.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: If it's not asking too much --  For our information just for illustration  Tell us how you intend to run the nation.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: These are the laws of my administration: No one's allowed to smoke or tell a dirty joke -- And whistling is forbidden...

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: You've made a wonderful impression. Your views are liberal... It is easy to see you have an open mind.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's what I get for dressing in a hurry.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Your Excellency, you mustn't forget your appointment at the House of Representatives... Have you got your speech ready?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I wrote a speech last night that'll knock them off their seats...  Four score and seven years ago, our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation --

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Why, that's the speech that Lincoln made at Gettysburg...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: He did?... I told my son not to leave it laying around... Where is son?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Oh, Rufus!

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: All I can offer you is a Rufus over your head.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Oh, Your Excellency, I don't know what to say.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: I wouldn't know what to say either if I was in your place.  Maybe you can suggest something.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: So -- you've come to ask for clemency! I'll give the enemy no quarter -- not a dime...

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: But Your Excellency -- the Ambassador is here on a friendly visit...  He came to ask you to patch up the breach.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Let him patch up his own breeches...

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Oh, won't you reconsider...

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well, maybe I am a little headstrong...  But, you know, it's awfully hard to forget what he called me.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Guard them with your life... don't leave them out of your sight...  If the enemy gets those papers  we're lost.  If they don't get them, we're lost.  Can't you see what I'm trying to tell you?  I love you...   Mrs. Teasdale, you're the salt of the earth.  They don't come any better than you...

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Now -- er --

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Well -- they might come better but they don't come any bigger... and the bigger the better.  The bigger the betta you've got on a horse, the more you lose, and speaking about horses, why don't you marry me. Come, come -- say yes and you'll never see me again.  I'll go 'way if it means your happiness...

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Oh, your Excellency, you take me off my feet.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Gloria -- may I call you Gloria?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Why -- why -- of course.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You can call me Gloria too.  Gloria -- what a beautiful name.  When I was born my mother named me Gloria -- two minutes later she found out her mistake...

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: I hope I'm not interrupting.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Take a seat -- you're next.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Your Excellency, something terrible has just happened.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: That's all right.  I'll fix you right up.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: My purse has been stolen -- the plans of war are in it.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: WHAT  ?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: I -- I may be wrong, but I suspect the Secretary of War.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: Don't bother me - I'm thinking -- What was that?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: I said - I suspect the Secretary of War.

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: THIS IS TREASON!!  What a fool I was to listen to your siren song and fall a helpless victim under the insidious spell of your irresistible charms --

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: But -

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You satisfied your selfish whims, while nations tottered, dynasties rocked and the world plunged headlong into a chasm of chaos and oblivion --  Not bad, eh?

turns.speaker: GROUCHO
turns.text: You know I think they think I should be king.  Although it would please me to govern the throng, suppose I were king and then everything went wrong.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: The king can do no wrong!

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Your uncle has been such a friend to us in every crisis.  Without his country's financial aid --

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: What is money?  Mrs. Teasdale, for you -- I would do anything.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Ambassador!  I am so anxious for you to meet our new dictator.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Mrs. Teasdale -- no matter who rules Freedonia, to me you will always be the first lady of the land.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: ...but would further cement the relations of our countries.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Ambassador Trentino, I am indeed honored...  But you see - well - I --

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Oh.  Then there his somebody else?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Well no -- not exactly -- but --

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Gloria -- I've waited for years.  I won't be put off!  I love you!  I want you!  Can't you see that I'm at your feet?

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Gentlemen!  Gentlemen!

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: I didn't come here to be insulted.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: I shall report this indignity the my President.  Mrs. Teasdale,  I feel this regrettable occurrence will plunge our countries into war.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: This is terrible!

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Mrs. Teasdale, I'm willing to pocket my pride and do anything I can to make up with his Excellency.

turns.speaker: MRS. TEASDALE
turns.text: Oh, would you...?

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: For you, I would do anything...

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: So that's the one you want to marry.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: With Mrs. Teasdale as my wife and Freedonia under my control --

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Maybe it's not going to be so easy. From what I've heard, Mrs. Teasdale is rather sweet on this Rufus T. Firefly.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: That's where you come in.  I'll leave him in your hands, and don't forget you're supposed to be my niece.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Uncle, you can't do this!

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: My dear niece -- I must ask you not to interfere.  War is not a woman's problem.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: It is every woman's problem.  Who supplies the sons? -- the brothers? -- the husbands?  Who...

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: This is all Firefly's fault -- that idiot, that fool...

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: I thought everything was working out fine.

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Fine nothing!  I didn't want war... My plan was to marry Mrs. Teasdale and overthrow Firefly.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Maybe you can still win the old dame over -- why not try to --

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: If only we can get his Excellency to listen to reason...

turns.speaker: TRENTINO
turns.text: Perhaps he will listen to you...

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Mr. Merrick, sugar?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Yes please, two.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: One or two?

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Two, please.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh yes. You have so many nice things, and so much room.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: And here is one of Frederick's mother.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: How lovely.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: They have noble faces.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: I've always thought that myself.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh... why Mr. Merrick she's beautiful.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: She has the face of an angel... She was an angel. She was so kind... so kind to me. It's not her fault, for in the fourth month of her maternal condition she was knocked down by an elephant. I'm sure I must have been a great disappointment to her.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Oh no, Mr. Merrick. No. No son as loving as you are could ever be a disappointment.

turns.speaker: MERRICK
turns.text: If only I could find her. If only she could see me now, here, with such lovely kind friends. You, Mrs. Treves, and you, Mr. Treves. Then maybe she would love me as I am. I've tried to hard to be good.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: You won't be long?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I'll join you shortly.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Did it go well, darling?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Yes, very well, I think. Are the girls in bed?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Yes, and they send their kisses. Would you like your sherry now?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: No, I think a whiskey.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Freddie?... Freddie, don't look so discouraged.

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I shouldn't be. We made great progress today. I taught him to repeat a few basic phrases. He did rather well, too, but I had to lead him every step of the way. Though frankly, at times I was unsure of who was leading whom.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: Well, I wasn't sure whether he was parroting me because that's all he was capable of, or whether he sensed that that's all I wanted to hear, and he was trying to please me.

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: But I thought you said that he was rather... simple?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: He is. I mean, I've always thought he was. I think he must be. Is he simple? Or is that just something I've wished upon him to make things simpler for myself?

turns.speaker: ANNE
turns.text: Frederick, why are you so interested in this particular case?

turns.speaker: TREVES
turns.text: I don't know. I can't explain it. If this is an intelligent man, trapped in the body of a monster, then I'm under a moral obligation to help free that mind, free that spirit as best I can, to help him live as full and content a life as possible. But! If he's an imbecile, who's body I can't treat and who's mind I can't touch, well, then my obligation is discharged. They can put him where they will; he won't be bothered, I won't be bothered, and everyone's conscience can remain free and untroubled. And that is my dilemma... what is in his mind?
